title: Monday, 23rd October, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning, welcome to Markets Live

PM11:02am

And I believe we have Bryce back in the saddle

PM11:02am

Which is a relief

11:02 am
PM11:02am

For all of us

BE11:02am

Thumbs up

PM11:02am

But let's have a pic for today

11:02 am
PM11:03am

https://upload.wik...edia/commons/1/14/Дерипаска_Олег_Владимирович.jpg

PM11:03am

Sorry

PM11:03am

Let me try a different link

11:03 am
PM11:03am

I want Oleg Deripaska

PM11:04am

But wary of getting some pap shot that will cost us $$$$

PM11:04am

Oh, google him yourself

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Or just imagine him

PM11:04am

Reason I share is that I have a question

PM11:04am

Rhetorical question

11:04 am
BE11:05am

PM11:05am

How come, if it's maybe the case that he couldn't list Rusal in London a few years back (rather than deciding not to)

PM11:05am

(Thx Bryce)

11:05 am
BE11:05am

A capture of a probably public image in the context of his Wikipedia entry, used in a topical context under fair dealing legislation. I'm not a lawyer AMA.

PM11:06am

Why is it then, that jsut a few years later he's able to bring us this En+ thing?

PM11:06am

And there's no debate, no questions asked.

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Suddenly he's got a London listing.

PM11:06am

Or will have

PM11:06am

https://www.invest...1710230700042981U/

11:07 am
BE11:07am

It's a GDR, right? Not, like, a proper listing.

PM11:07am

So Oleg maybe didn't qualify for a premium London listing, but it's just fine for him to have a GDR listing -- and declare himself to be "listing on the London stock market"

PM11:08am

Yeah

11:08 am
PM11:08am

This is another example of the LSE just renting out London's reputation

PM11:08am

Anyway, I'd better not say any more Censored

PM11:08am

For obvious reasons

11:08 am
undefined
PM11:09am

Anyway, welcome back Bryce

BE11:09am

I mean, this argument is somewhat circular. Saying you're "listing on the London market" is only useful if it has some connected respectability and kudos, which every duffer listing tarnishes. Yes, hello!

11:09 am
PM11:09am

I see you've brought some M&A back with you

BE11:09am

Spire? Hm.

BE11:10am

Tad surprised it was a Sunday Times exclusive ....

11:10 am
PM11:10am

So this was around the middle of last week -- was mentioned in a couple of market reports

PM11:10am

But people dismissed cos Spire shot to bits after that NHS stuff last month

PM11:10am

I think there will be a hell of a stewards on this

11:10 am
BE11:10am

The idea here is that Mediclinic's gone in opportunistically.

BE11:11am

The connected idea would involve speculating about why it was leaked, and by which side. Because there seems to be a degree of expectation for another bid.

PM11:12am

All involved must have known it had leaked by Friday.

11:12 am
BE11:13am

They were ready to confirm on the first proper media report, I believe.

BE11:13am

(Which no longer includes market reports, by the looks of things. And fair enough really. We'd done "Spire-Mediclinic" in the paper once a month for about three years.)

PM11:14am

The rules don't say "wait for proper media." They say "if you think it's leaked, release the info.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Hm. Perhaps you should raise your concerns about lax regulation of the London market with the Panel.

BE11:15am

So anyway ..... 150p in cash and 0.232 new
Mediclinic shares, which is slightly less than 300p per share at current prices.

Mediclinic International PLC (MDC:LSE): Last: 634.50, down 6 (-0.94%), High: 647.00, Low: 623.00, Volume: 939.60k
11:16 am
Spire Healthcare Group PLC (SPI:LSE): Last: 293.40, up 32.1 (+12.28%), High: 300.00, Low: 286.10, Volume: 16.34m
BE11:16am

... equivalent to 18.7x 2018 Reuters Consensus PE, says Citi .....

BE11:17am

.... whose further working does rather emphasise how much this one leaked.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The offer represents a 30% premium to closing Spire price on 17 October, 31% premium to 30-day VWAP prior to the offer and 14% to Friday’s price.

PM11:17am

hehehe

BE11:17am

And as to the price ......

11:17 am
BE11:18am

Opportunistic but not unexpected — The offer valuation is below where Spire was trading prior to its H1 trading update (more than 310p), which sent the stock down more than 15% In that note, we argued that the Spire sell-off could be a catalyst for Mediclinic make an offer. Although the current offer may not come at good time for Mediclinic, given ongoing integration challenges at Al Noor, we think the overwhelming driver of the offer is that Mediclinic thinks it could get Spire at an attractive valuation. For the same reason, however, it is more difficult for the Spire Board to recommend such an offer given the depressed EPS base and share price, off of which, Mediclinic is valuing Spire. Since our August 2015 initiation on Mediclinic, we argued that they would in-time attempt to wholly own Spire

BE11:18am

The original offer looks like it would have been marginally accretive for Mediclinic EPS — The equity swap component would have been accretive, with Mediclinic equity valued at PE multiple (20.5x rolled one year forward, CitiE) premium to Spire. It was not stated how the cash portion of the consideration would be funded, but we expect a combination of new debt taken on the SA, UAE and UK balance sheets would be preferred. Depending on willingness to assume debt in the UAE, a small equity raise may have been necessary too.

BE11:19am

What might Mediclinic do next? — Given the above, we think it would be naïve on Mediclinic’s behalf for them to expect this first offer would have been accepted, so in all likelihood, they should already be prepared to make a second offer. However, offering a higher premium would make it harder for the deal to make sense from and EPS/returns perspective. Nonetheless, given Mediclinic’s interest in Spire’s long-term prospects, we believe management and shareholders can look past negative short-term dilutions. A greater weighting to cash (as opposed to Mediclinic shares) in the offer could also be more appealing to Spire shareholders. However, raising the bid and/or cash portion would also raise the probability Mediclinic would undertake an equity offer to fund the cash portion.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

And Berenberg, saying similar.

BE11:19am

Mediclinic’s management should be applauded for seeing an opportunity to acquire the remaining Spire’s shares cheaply, in our view, given the sharp share price reaction to Spire’s most recent profit warning. While the bid is c10% above our price target, there is relatively little in the value for a control premium, in our view, and given that the long-term prospects for Spire are strong (underinvestment by the NHS, substantial capex invested over the past four years), we believe that it would have to pay substantially more to garner board approval.

BE11:20am

We believe that the recent share price move was triggered by lower NHS demand and fears that demand would decline further. Latest NHS data (see our last research report) indicates that demand is stable, rather than worsening, helping to support a rebound in the shares. The near-term investment thesis is not without risks, given the poorly thought-through edicts to emerge from the NHS, but we would consider a bid in the upper half of the last two years’ 315-355p/share trading range to be more acceptable. We expect this to be an opening salvo from Mediclinic, which has until 20 November to make a formal bid.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Should speculation that HCA would also be interested in acquiring Spire be correct (source:
The Times), this bid from Mediclinic could encourage it to act, although with Mediclinic having now publicly announced its intention to acquire all of Spire, it appears less likely that HCA would be able to acquire Mediclinic’s 29.9% stake in Spire.
● Our 270p/share price target is based on 9-10x EBITDA, which represents a discount to Spire’s peers due to lower growth, but acknowledges the strong free cash flow yield and a low price-to-book value. It does not reflect the current Mediclinic bid situation.

BE11:21am

There was a suggestion going round six or so weeks ago about Mediclinic weighing up whether to sell its stake to HCA, wasn't there?

PM11:21am

So the chances of a counter are slim

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Yeah, you'd have thought. Mediclinic's the kingmaker here.

PM11:22am

Indeed

undefined
11:22 am
BE11:22am

And it seems not improbable to me for it to just sit tight, given the uncertainties on NHS spending, but that's not the sellside view.

undefined
BE11:23am

So, what else?

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Should we look at the day's blow up?

PM11:23am

Daily blow ups are a thing now

BE11:23am

Pendragon? ROTR seems interested.

11:23 am
Pendragon PLC (PDG:LSE): Last: 23.95, down 5.05 (-17.41%), High: 25.49, Low: 22.25, Volume: 7.24m
BE11:24am

Good story, this. 20% downgrade to 2017 because of some price war between two "premium" marques.

PM11:24am

https://www.invest...1710230700032670U/

11:24 am
BE11:25am

I don't know enough about cars to say which two marques those are, but I'm sure someone on the right can make an educated guess.

BE11:25am

So, £60m PBT rather than the £75m expected

BE11:26am

And an accelerated strategic review to see what's going wrong.

11:26 am
PM11:26am

(The point I've been trying to make in your absence is that if common/garden profit warning now = 20-30% off the stock price, how is the wider market going to respond to a big index moving event. Because they do happen.)

BE11:27am

(It's a good question. I might just have to write 850 words on it for later this week.)

BE11:27am

Here's Berenberg.

11:27 am
PM11:28am

(Thumbs up)

BE11:28am

Despite making all the right moves with regard to strategic positioning – ie continuing to lessen their exposure to new car franchises – some premium car manufacturers (two in particular) have continued “to force volume into the market despite softening demand”, according to management. This has caused material pressure on premium vehicle margins. The outcome is that Pendragon expects PBT to be in the region of £60m in 2017, c20% lower than consensus expectations. While the market today has priced this into the shares, the long-term story of doubling its used car business remains intact. We do, however, recognise that there is an added level of uncertainty about how OEM and dealer relationships will evolve in the short term. With this in mind, we downgrade our recommendation to Hold and move our price target to 26p.

BE11:29am

Snowball effect: In April 2017, premium new car sales became the subject of additional tax changes, which in effect made these vehicles more expensive to purchase. The outcome was materially lower premium sales in Q2 across the industry. With this trend continuing into Q3, dealerships were forced to pre-register vehicles if they were to hit OEM targets. However, pre-registrations damage prices, not only on new car margins but also on those of demo, nearly new and used vehicles. While preregistrations have been a feature of the UK market for years, the sustained period of softer demand has arguably been worse than expected. In order to sell these vehicles (and two premium brands in particular, as they look to clear stock), Pendragon’s margins have come under short but sharp pressure. While its inventory turn has remained strong – a clear positive – the aforementioned issues have created a c£10m drag to the company’s profit in Q3. Pendragon, however, proved in 2008/09 that these pressures are often short-lived and that margins are usually quick to recover (partly because Pendragon can re-buy stock at cheaper prices). We would watch closely for how this develops and if signals indicate a recovery here, this could open up an opportunity.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Pendragon has undertaken a review into its new car
business and will continue to evaluate the return on capital asked of it by OEMs. Pendragon has already closed/sold 46 UK franchises in recent years and we believe today’s news could result in a further rise in closures over the coming years. With no further investment to be made either into its US business, this could be an avenue to realise value. New chairman Chris Chambers possesses a wealth of capital markets experience, and we are confident that strategic options will be considered.

BE11:30am

..... and good luck on its reinvention as a software company.

undefined
11:31 am
BE11:31am

The day's other warning is Dialight ......

Dialight PLC (DIA:LSE): Last: 690.84, down 124.16 (-15.23%), High: 700.00, Low: 660.00, Volume: 45.19k
PM11:32am

Repeat offender, this one

11:32 am
PM11:32am

I believe

BE11:32am

Yep. Blame goes on the fix for the last warning.

BE11:32am

As in, it decided to switch to an outsourcing partner to minimise risk.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

And guess what! It's made a hash of it!

PM11:33am

hehehe

BE11:33am

Component shortages, delayed deliveries, that kind of thing.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

You could see it all as a temporary, operational problem. But to see it that way requires a rather selective view of history.

PM11:02am

A few bits and pieces going on

BE11:34am

Year of change. 2017 was always going to present multiple challenges, due Dialight’s ambitious programme of product regeneration and the move from in-house to outsourced production. The challenges have been overcome, to the extent that all of the products are now platform-based, re-certified and handed over for production by Sanmina in Mexico. However, the timescale has been stretched by some of the issues, including global certifications and now production ramp-up. We expect them to be resolved in due course.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Estimates. We have reduced our estimates of revenue and earnings, to reflect the pessimistic end of the company’s guidance range, based on what can realistically be shipped during 2017 and the following year. None of the issues governing the rate of production are insuperable, but they will need time to be resolved fully. Our estimates do still reflect a sharp rise in Lighting year-on-year in 2018E and 2019E, as execution improves. Our estimates assume that end market demand remains subdued, although the economic drivers for adoption of LED industrial lighting are as robust as ever.

BE11:35am

Growth story. Although it is disappointing to cut estimates, these had endured since 2016, before the ‘heavy lifting’ of the transformation had really started and during a period when expectations for many other companies have been trimmed back, including some operating in Dialight’s space. Looking forward, we still see an excellent growth story and the emergence of a capital-light and cash-rich company with its strong IP base intact. Our EV/EBITDA-based valuation comes down by 12% but we reiterate Buy. We consider that the shares have already discounted the issues that Dialight has encountered.

undefined
11:35 am
BE11:36am

So, to bring myself up to speed on return from holiday, I read a report on pension fund deficits.

PM11:36am

Oh yeah?

BE11:36am

And it's quite interesting!

11:36 am
BE11:36am

it's this thumper, from RBC.

BE11:36am

BE11:37am

I'm not sure if those men are meant to pallbearers for the interest rate or whether there's some other kind of symbolism to carrying it uphill during sunset, but perhaps I'm overthinking.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Gist here is to buy pension holes. Or rather, don't.

BE11:37am

Because they won't be holes soon.

BE11:37am

UK pension schemes have just moved out of deficit and into surplus for the first time since 2000. In addition, an imminent increase to assumed discount rates should significantly improve that surplus. We do not believe share prices have factored in this improvement and we recommend investors buy a basket of pensions-exposed stocks.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

So, as to the discount rate .........

BE11:38am

Under IAS19, the assumed discount rate is a high quality corporate bond yield. However such corporate bonds are few and far between at durations in excess of 30 years. Therefore discount rates tend to be based on gilt yields at those long durations. Actuarial consultants are starting to encourage schemes to adopt a (higher) corporate bond yield at long durations. We expect schemes will increase discount rates by 0.3%, in line with the move by Tesco, and calculate that the aggregate surplus will improve by £41bn. The triennial funding valuation, which determines the employer contribution, should be unaffected.

BE11:38am

And also, death. Death is now working in investors' favour.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Or, as RBC puts it, there's been a "slowdown in life expectancy improvement since 2011", which isn't yet in the mortality tables.

PM11:39am

So how do they know?

BE11:39am

............ pass.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

 Male life expectancy at age 65 has dropped significantly by 11 months to 22.3 years.
 Female life expectancy has dropped by 6 months to 23.9 years.

PM11:39am

Blimey

BE11:40am

Not sure where that data's cropped from. ONS maybe? But, yes, interesting trend.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

And I'm open to speculation on why it's happening, if it is happening, which I guess it might not be.

BE11:41am

Anyway, this all adds up to a surplus of £54bn for the FTSE 100 companies.

BE11:41am

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Which is quite a lot.

BE11:41am

BE11:41am

Or, on a more detailed view ....

11:41 am
BE11:41am

PM11:42am

right click, fresh tab

BE11:42am

We should set that up as an autotext.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

And because triennial reviews take about 18 months to be published, investors haven't priced it in yet, says RBC.

PM11:42am

Dunno how we do those with the new kit

BE11:42am

The basket of pensions-exposed stocks has underperformed by 26.2% since December 2015 and we believe this creates a buying opportunity

11:43 am
BE11:43am

..... which, given it's about actuarial tables, is quite interesting right?

BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 274.22, up 3.37 (+1.24%), High: 274.30, Low: 270.65, Volume: 4.88m
Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 66.86, down 0.14 (-0.21%), High: 67.25, Low: 66.49, Volume: 47.29m

undefined
11:43 am
PM11:44am

Actual, just on profit warnings...

PM11:44am

Have you read the Real Good Food statement

PM11:44am

??

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Nope.

PM11:44am

It's a fantastic shambles

PM11:45am

https://www.invest...1710230700042722U/

11:45 am
PM11:45am

Everything that could have gone wrong, has gone wrong

PM11:45am

So they are retreating to Liverpool

PM11:47am

I don't know who covers it

11:46 am
Real Good Food PLC (RGD:LSE): Last: 22.99, down 3.01 (-11.58%), High: 24.00, Low: 21.00, Volume: 53.39k
PM11:47am

Nothing in my inbox

BE11:47am

Finncap is shop, but they only have one line out that's basically just a shrug.

11:47 am
undefined
BE11:48am

Just remembered -- Real Good Food is the company that said its FY was fine in July then warned in August.

BE11:49am

That's on a March year end. The thing's a disaster.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Anyway, what else? I see the ROTR are going on about housebuilders again.

BE11:50am

Credit Suisse has a big UK strategy thing out today where they note that housebuilders don't tend to do well as rates rise.

PM11:51am

A UK deep dive

11:51 am
BE11:51am

That's the one.

BE11:51am

We take UK domestic banks to overweight from a small underweight as a result of: relative valuation; the structure of the UK sector; the end of litigation/PPI claims; and UK banks can outperform when house prices fall. We focus on Lloyds and Barclays. We finance this by taking UK life insurance to benchmark from overweight. UK life is no longer especially sensitive to bond yields, no longer cheap against asset managers (which are being highly disrupted) and, in some instances, they are highly sensitive to higher credit spreads (L&G is rated Underperform). We take UK housebuilders to a small underweight from benchmark. The sector underperforms 80% of the time in the six months after the first rate hike; the sector's P/B is at an all-time high; London house prices are falling, yet the national homebuilders seem to be discounting a c5% rise; and political tailwinds can get no better. We highlight Berkeley Group rated Underperform

BE11:52am

The fun stuff comes a lot later though.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

Think CS been negative on Berkeley for a while now

PM11:53am

Go on

BE11:53am

..... They have. They're also quite negative on Carney, and on Labour.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

What are the implications of a Labour administration?
■ Higher gilt yields: Labour wants to increase spending by 2% of GDP but finance this by raising the corporate tax rate to 26%, reducing the 45% marginal personal income tax rate threshold to £80k, and re-introducing the top 50% marginal rate on earnings above £123k. We believe that such a proposal would not be revenue-neutral and thus there will likely be much larger deficits than under a Conservative government (see the IFS's assessment of both parties' 2017 manifesto proposals on public finances here). Labour has also restated its commitment to abolishing tuition fees, which would cost
around £11bn a year annually on top of a potential one-off £60bn cost to write off existing student debt (for students that enrolled after 2011).
■ Public finances: These would deteriorate sharply as the top 1% of UK tax payers account for 27% of all income tax. We believe that if Labour were to threaten a punitive tax regime, many of top 1%, who are highly mobile, would leave the UK.
■ Higher inflation: Thus far, Labour has stated there will be no cap on public sector pay rises and is talking about a £10 per hour minimum wage. This would be inflationary.
■ Independence of the BoE could be threatened: The Labour leader, Jeremy Corbyn, has talked about 'People’s QE'; the central bank directly financing infrastructure projects (note that this is possible as effectively the BoE's charter can be determined by the Chancellor). This would be inflationary.
■ Sterling: If Labour imposes punitive taxation, or hints at limiting the independence of the BoE, then there would be a risk of substantial capital flight (at a time when FDI is 5% of GDP). Under a Labour government, we cannot exclude such a scenario. This would offset what would be a sterling-supportive policy of fiscal easing and a milder stance towards Brexit

BE11:55am

And it's the house view that a November hike will be a mistake.

BE11:57am

So, buy euro earners and sell dollar earners.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

BE11:58am

That's Pearson, Tate, BAE, Experian, Carnival with about half of sales in $.

BE11:59am

But back to where we came in, on the housebuilders.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

BE12:00pm

BE12:00pm

Starts outpacing sales in London is interesting, right? Have to suspect that's because builders have been building the wrong types of houses.

12:01 pm
undefined
PM12:01pm

Look at the time

PM12:01pm

But Bryce, before we go

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

Here's another thing that happened while you were away...

PM12:02pm

Which we can maybe discuss later in the week

PM12:02pm

...

12:02 pm
PM12:02pm

Ocado: £239.29; Asda: £239.43

BE12:02pm

.............. ?

PM12:02pm

Yes, Ocado have joined the grocery price war

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

£239.43 is a hell of a lot of groceries. So's £239.29.

PM12:03pm

Here's a quick CS par... But we can discuss another time, cos I just don't see how Ocado can compete on price when they are not yet even profitable (really)

PM12:03pm

Ocado maintains pricing pressure. A remarkable 4-week shift in pricing
strategy is becoming clear as the total price for Ocado's last four baskets
matched Asda's almost penny for penny (Ocado: £239.29; Asda: £239.43),
and is now the lowest-priced grocer in our analysis. As we noted two weeks
ago, "winning" the pricing game is not always desirable; it may be an
attempt to reset expectations or drive volume – in both cases it is
expensive from a margin perspective. It is also potentially more challenging
for Ocado to get this price message across to consumers given their low
overall advertising spend. Mike Coupe, Sainsbury's CEO has said that it
takes ~12 weeks for consumers to internalise a new pricing structure; we
will see if this new pricing level lasts that long.

12:03 pm
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 291.80, down 0.1 (-0.03%), High: 292.00, Low: 290.10, Volume: 243.10k
BE12:04pm

Cripes! That's interesting.

PM12:04pm

I know

12:04 pm
PM12:04pm

But we are over time

PM12:04pm

Thanks for joining us on the right.

PM12:05pm

And it's nice to have you back Bryce

12:04 pm
PM12:05pm

PM12:05pm

BE12:05pm

As we know, Ocado has a lot of warehouse capacity to fill. And there have been suggestions that it's struggling to hit the kind of critical mass required to take its own deliveries but .... oh ..... we're over time. Bye.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Here's Investec.
